DOC.brief_summary: The standard treatment of posterior semicircular canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the canalith repositioning procedure or the Epley maneuver. Based on the present literature, there is controversy on the efficacy of post-maneuver postural restrictions.The aim of this study was to conduct a randomized controlled trial to compare the treatment efficacy of post-maneuver postural restriction with CRP alone in patients with posterior semicircular canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.
DOC.brief_title: Efficacy of Postural Restriction in Treating Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo
DOC.detailed_description: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the most common cause of vertigo. Based on the present literature, there is controversy on the efficacy of post-maneuver postural restrictions.Some study designs were not randomized controlled trials. The present study offers an alternative way of postural restriction to maintain postural restriction as much as possible.
DOC.criteria: Patients with unilateral posterior semicircular canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo and A negative neurologic examination Secondary benign paroxysmal positional vertigo caused by trauma head injury, inner ear surgery, viral labyrinthitis or Meniere's disease Patients with central vertigo, cervical spine, neurologic, otologic, psychiatric diseases Patients who used medications that affected the neurologic and otologic systems for less than 48 hours
DOC.keyword: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo, Postural Restriction
